CHUNGKING
Oct. 29th, 1938
Personal
Mr. S. W. Morgen,
Pan American Airways,
Now York, N. I.
Dear Mr. Morgan,
Everything has been noving so rapidly
- the last weok
or so I have juat about lost all track of
time.
In ay
letter of
Oct»
19th I again predicted the fall of Hankow but I certainly had no idea
it would fall Bo soon.
On the twenty
first we received some urgent nessages
from the Minister who was in Hankow requesting us to immediately increase
our service to Hankow and advising us confidentially that the city was
axpected to be completely evacuated by the 25th.
I also got several
personal messages over the commercial telegraph fron government officials
I knew asking me to arrange charter trips for them so
it waa evident the
situation in Hankow was getting
It was impossible to increase our schedules with the
flying boats as they were practically flying every day anyway so the
only thing we could do would be to use the DC-twos at night.
We could go
into Hankow at night safely because the military field is equipped for
night flying
and the country all around is flat, but night flying into
Chungking
is
impossible except on very rare occasions.
We therefore would
have to fly from Hunkow to Chengtu, He therefore agreed to fly from
Chungking
to Hankow, leaving so as to arrive in Hankow soon after dark and
then fly to Chengtu and back to lankow arriving just before day light and
then make a second flight out of Hankow for Chungking-
We decided to drop
and take fifteen passengers.
This was a rather ambitious
schedule and would require every break in order to accomplish it.
had two pilots with night flying experience who could do it, Sharp and
Leonard and Sharp was in Hongkong•
Also there were no night landing
facilities at Chengtu, so we would have to arrange for them. We therefore
sent Leonard
instructions
to return that night with Sharp. I sent Sharp a measage
get a floodlight that would work from a storage battery, and be prepared to
Chungking with Leonard.
They both arrived about nine o'clock on
I discussed the situation with them and they
could be done.
Leonard who had been flying nearly all night
went up
to
where I live and went to bed.
He sent Nich to Chengtu with the
flood
light and
a lot of lanterns to arrange for the lights and to have gas
and o11
and
₴.
service crew on the field.
Just as Sharp was leaving the
